intro: Gilia collina, commonly known as mountain gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high elevations, often in open meadows or along stream banks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branching. Gilia collina is an important nectar source for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
